briefOverview: A short revelation promising that the prophet Elijah will return to restore the priesthood before the Lord’s final day and to re-establish covenantal ties between generations.
summary: The text announces that Elijah will reveal the Priesthood before the coming of the "great and dreadful day of the Lord." It says Elijah will "plant in the hearts of the children the promises made to the fathers," causing "the hearts of the children [to] turn to their fathers." The chapter concludes with the claim that, without this turning of hearts, the whole earth would be utterly wasted at the Lord’s coming, linking priesthood restoration, family reconciliation, and eschatological preservation.
externalContext: This passage appears in the early Latter-day Saint canon as part of revelations given in the 19th-century American Restoration movement associated with Joseph Smith. It draws on a longstanding Jewish and Christian expectation—rooted in the Hebrew prophets—that Elijah would return before the final day of the Lord, a motif influential in Second Temple Judaism and later Christian interpretation. The emphasis on priesthood restoration and turning of hearts also reflects concerns central to the movement: restoring ancient authority and renewing covenantal family bonds.
externalReferences: The language closely echoes Malachi 4:5–6, which prophesies that God will send Elijah before the day of the Lord to turn the hearts of fathers to children and children to fathers. Luke 1:17 applies the spirit and power of Elijah to John the Baptist as a forerunner, showing a New Testament engagement with the Elijah motif. The phrase "promises made to the fathers" is plausibly connected to the Abrahamic covenant language found in Genesis 12:1–3, where blessings promised to the patriarchs are foundational to later claims about covenant continuity.
practicalQuestions: How might the idea of "turning hearts" between generations shape how families approach reconciliation and shared religious memory today?
In what concrete ways can a faith community work to 'restore' or pass on spiritual authority and commitments across generations?
What practices (e.g., family history, storytelling, ritual) best foster continuity with ancestral promises in a modern context?
How should believers balance expectancy of a future "day of the Lord" with present ethical and communal responsibilities?
uncertainAreas: Ambiguity remains about whether the reference to Elijah denotes the literal historical prophet, a typological figure (as with John the Baptist), or a future agent acting in Elijah's name; the text does not specify. The exact content of the "promises made to the fathers" is not spelled out here (likely Abrahamic covenants, but not detailed). The meaning of the earth being "utterly wasted" is open to literal or symbolic readings.
